text:
I'm thinking of starting a project where I need to use a deep learning library. Not sure whether to do it in Python or Julia. Of course I prefer Julia, but I'm unsure about Julia's DL capabilities. How is Flux these days? Relatively stable and fast? Does it have GPU acceleration? I prefer "stable and reliable" over "have exciting new features for autodiff".
Edit: And is Flux still the go-to library?

>  Relatively stable and fast?
Yes
>  Does it have GPU acceleration? 
Yes
>  is Flux still the go-to library?
Yes, (though as always there are options)

Flux might still have some rough edges, but you won’t have trouble with them since you are familar with julia.
So won’t go around doing things like writing type-unstable code etc.

text: If it's just DNNs, I don't think you will run into big issues with Flux. Performance seemed to be pretty on-par with Tensorflow for me and setting up CUDA.jl is really a breeze. It's of course not quite as stable as something like Tensorflow, so if you really need something guaranteed to be rock-solid, TF might be the better way to go, but otherwise I'd consider Flux a solid option
